abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is highly
            unsatisfactory. Construction and rehabilitation achievements
            of health centers, and of the Ministry of Health (MOH)
            buildings, were successful, yet, these were later found to
            be underutilized, and deteriorating. The project failed in
            strengthening management capacity at central, regional, and
            delivery levels, including in major hospitals. The health
            management information system, never became operational,
            which hindered the health strategy, and decision capacity of
            the MOH. Several key lessons may be drawn from the project:
            1) Upon identification of risks, such as poor management
            capacity, and implementation by the Borrower, adequate
            technical assistance (TA), and institutional support should
            be planned for project implementation. This TA should work
            closely with, and transfer skills to qualified national
            counterparts. 2) Project ownership should be ensured,
            through staff continuity, from the Bank, as from the
            government, to achieve the necessary involvement, as of
            preparation, through full implementation. 3) The lack of
            adequate supervision by Bank staff, prevented addressing
            potential risks, which could have solved project
            difficulties - particularly in a complex case, and a weak
            Borrower capacity. 4) The continued lack of reaction from
            the Bank's management, needs to be addressed as an
            institutional weakness, which severely compromises its credibility.

18156674.theme: Health system performance,Administrative and civil service reform,Malaria
18156674.trustfund:
TF020430-AUSTRIAN CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF037402-EQUATORIAL GUINEA - HEALTH
            IMPROVEMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has four major components:
            (i) Institutional strengthening of the Ministry of Health
            (MOH) to provide restructuring of the MOH services, training
            workshops and seminars for staff at all levels, health
            center reconstruction and MOH office rehabilitation works,
            furniture and medical equipment. Reforms aimed at management
            and financial autonomy for the main hospitals of Malabo and
            Bata are to be initiated in collaboration with French aid.
            (ii) Health strategy development and implementation
            establishing a management information system and a health
            planning unit in MOH. (iii) Human resource development to
            train health sector personnel and improve MOH's
            technical and management capacity at all levels of the
            health system. (iv) Strengthening of priority health
            programs to improve MOH's operational capabilities and
            testing of new approaches to health care delivery by
            strengthening field work in malaria control, mother and
            child health and family planning, sexually transmitted
            diseases, and by providing essential generic drugs, with a
            special focus on most vulnerable groups. The project
            finances the rehabilitation of four rural health centers in
            the remote rural districts of Micomiseng and Acurenam;
            equipment for the mother and child and family clinics in
            Malabo and Bata, and supplies of essential medical materials
            and drugs to all these facilities. Cost recovery is
            introduced through a differentiated fee structure.
